Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project jointly funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), Professor Jason Chen of Iowa State University is developing methods to prepare complex polyoxygenated molecules. Educational modules in development by Professor Chen introduce local high school students to the importance of organic chemistry in modern medicine. The broader impacts of this work include potential advances in synthetic organic chemistry from the discovery of new methods to install dense arrays of oxygen-containing stereocenters and the encouragement of high school students to pursue STEM careers.

The methods emphasize tunable control over the placement of the oxygen atoms and the ability to introduce multiple oxygen atoms at the same time. This project focuses on setting multiple contiguous alcohol chiral centers with flexible stereochemistry. The key reactions are enantioselective, organocatalytic, polyoxygenation of enals and nucleophilic addition to alpha-oxygenated aldehydes. These reactions complement each other and can potentially deliver up to five contiguous stereocenters in two steps. The polyoxygenated structures prepared by these methods are commonly found in molecules with useful biological properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jason Chen of Iowa State University worked on the development of reactions that enable rapid and stereochemically-flexible preparation of molecules containing two or more oxygen-containing functional groups on adjacent carbon atoms. Such chemical motifs are commonly found in bioactive molecules that are useful as biochemical probes or as potential therapeutics. The methods employ simple aldehyde starting materials and take advantage of readily-available amino acid-derived catalysts.

 

As part of this research, the Chen research group described the first example of a reaction that simultaneously functionalizes the alpha, beta, and gamma positions of an alpha,beta-unsaturated enal. The Chen group also elucidated the mechanistic details of this complex cascade reaction, thus setting the stage for the development of related cascade reactions. Additionally, in collaboration with Theresa Windus’ group at Iowa State University, the Chen group studied the stereochemistry-dependent folding of the partially-protected polyols formed in their reactions. Understanding the three-dimensional shape of the molecules formed in the above reactions is expected to empower the design of molecules with backbone carbon chains that turn in a prescribed manner; such control may promote selective binding to another compound (e.g., for catalysis or for drug discovery) or provide tunable a stereochemical preference for a subsequent reaction.

 

In addition to pushing the frontiers of stereoselective polyol synthesis, Chen extended his outreach efforts at Hoover High School. Located in the Des Moines Public School District, Hoover High School is an urban school with a high percentage of students from underrepresented ethnicities and/or economically-disadvantaged families. Chen participated in the school’s newly-funded STEM Academy and met regularly with the AP Chemistry class.
